Alter: pages, isbn. Add: pmc, doi, pages. Removed parameters. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Sir Victor Ewings Negus''', MS, [[Fellowship of the Royal College of Surgeons|FRCS]] (6 February 1887 – 15 July 1974) was a British surgeon who specialised in [[laryngology]] and also made fundamental contributions to [[comparative anatomy]] with his work on the structure and evolution of the [[larynx]]. He was born and educated in London, studying at [[King's College School]], then [[King's College London]], followed by [[King's College Hospital]]. The final years of his medical training were interrupted by the [[First World War]], during which he served with the [[Royal Army Medical Corps]]. After the war, he qualified as a surgeon and studied with laryngologists in France and the USA before resuming his career at King's College Hospital where he became a junior surgeon in 1924.
In the 1920s, Negus worked on aspects of both throat surgery and the anatomy of the larynx, the latter work contributing to his degree of [[Master of Surgery]] (1924). His surgical innovations included designs for [[laryngoscope]]s, [[bronchoscope]]s, [[oesophagoscope]]s, an operating table, and [[tracheotomy]] equipment. His major publications were ''The Mechanism of the Larynx'' (1929) and his work on the clinical text ''Diseases of the Nose and Throat'', starting with the fourth edition of 1937. Negus was also awarded several lectureships and published many medical papers and other works on comparative anatomy and laryngology. He became a senior surgeon at King's College Hospital in 1940 and a [[consultant (medicine)|consulting surgeon]] in 1946.
Negus was one of the founders of the British Association of Otorhinolaryngologists, helping to establish his speciality as a discipline within the newly formed [[National Health Service]]. He was a member of numerous international and national [[otolaryngology]] organisations, and presided over the Fourth International Congress of Otolaryngology in London in 1949. In this period of his career following the Second World War he also worked on the anatomy of the [[paranasal sinuses]], and played a key role in rebuilding and establishing collections of animal dissections used by comparative anatomists.
Negus, who married in 1929 and had two sons, retired in 1952, though he continued to publish on comparative anatomy and the history of medicine. His honours before and after retirement included the Fellowship of King's College, London (1945), an honorary degree (1950), the [[Lister Medal]] (1954), a knighthood (1956), honorary fellowships of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] (1949) and the [[Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland]] (1958), and the Honorary Gold Medal of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of England]] (1969). He died in Hindhead, Surrey, aged 87 in 1974.
==Early life and education== [[File:King's College London Chapel 2, London - Diliff.jpg|thumb|right|The chapel of King's College, where Negus studied at university]] Victor Ewings Negus was born on 6 February 1887 in [[Tooting]], London, the youngest of three sons of William and Emily Negus (née Ewings).<ref name="ODNB">{{cite encyclopedia |last=Weir| first=Neil |title=Negus, Sir Victor Ewings (1887–1974)|encyclopedia=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] |publisher= Oxford University Press |year= 2004 |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/57671 |accessdate= 26 December 2011 }} {{ODNBsub}}</ref> His father was a solicitor, [[Justice of the Peace]], and [[Deputy Lieutenant]] for the County of Surrey.<ref name="ODNB"/><ref name="WhoWasWho">{{cite encyclopedia |title=Negus, Sir Victor|encyclopedia=[[Who Was Who]] |publisher= A & C Black, 1920–2008; online edition, Oxford University Press |date= December 2007 |url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U157923 |accessdate= 26 December 2011 |format= subscription required}}</ref> Victor's pre-university education took place at [[King's College School]].<ref name="BMJObit">{{cite journal |date=27 July 1974 |title=Sir Victor Negus |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=3 |issue=5925 |page=263 |pmc=1611986 |pmid=4603002}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|King's College School, instituted in 1829 and opened in 1831, had originally been located in the premises of [[King's College London]] on the [[Strand, London|Strand]] in Central London, but moved to [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]] in South-West London in 1897.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cgi-bin/vcdf/detail?coll_id=3073&inst_id=6| title=King's College School| work=AIM25 collection description| publisher=AIM25 [Archives in London and the M25 area]| accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref>|group="n"}} In 1906, he was awarded a Sambrooke scholarship to [[King's College London]], on the [[Strand, London|Strand]], where his studies for the next three years included premedical and preclinical subjects.<ref name="BMJObit"/><ref name="TheTimesObit">{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Obituary: Sir Victor Negus – Distinguished laryngologist |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=17 July 1974 |page_number= 18 |issue= 59141|column= F}}</ref>
After passing the required examinations, Negus proceeded in 1909 to the next stage of his basic medical education at the nearby [[King's College Hospital]], at that time located on Portugal Street between the Strand and [[Lincoln's Inn Fields]].<ref name="BMJObit"/>{{#tag:ref|King's College Hospital had been founded in Portugal Street in 1839 and opened in 1840. That site, where Negus studied, closed in 1913 after King's College Hospital moved to [[Denmark Hill]], south of the river, where the building of new facilities had started in 1909.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cgi-bin/vcdf/detail?coll_id=804&inst_id=6| title=King's College Hospital| work=AIM25 collection description| publisher=AIM25 [Archives in London and the M25 area]| accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Lister Oration"/>|group="n"}} Three more years of study led to the attainment in 1912 of the [[Membership of the Royal College of Surgeons|MRCS]] and [[LRCP]] (Membership of the Royal College of Surgeons and Licentiate of the Royal College of Physicians, known as the '[[conjoint|conjoint diploma]]'), marking his formal qualification to practice medicine.<ref name="ODNB"/> In the final year of these studies, Negus was an usher at the funeral service for [[Lord Lister]] at [[Westminster Abbey]].<ref name="BMJObit"/> Another connection with Lister's generation came when Negus worked as surgical dresser and house surgeon under Sir [[William Watson Cheyne]], who had himself been house surgeon to Lister.<ref name="Lister Oration"/>{{#tag:ref|At the time of his death, Lister was renowned for the impact his work on antiseptic surgery had had on the medical profession. His funeral service on 16 February 1912 was a grand affair, attended by representatives from all over Europe. A contemporary description was given in the ''British Medical Journal''.<ref>{{cite journal |date=24 February 1912 |title=Funeral of Lord Lister |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=2669 |pages=440–442 |pmc=2345217 |pmid=20766030 |doi=10.1136/bmj.1.2669.438-a}}</ref> Negus, in the opening remarks for his 1955 Lister Oration some 43 years later, described it as a "moving ceremony".<ref name="Lister Oration"/> The impact of Lister on Negus and his generation can be seen in additional remarks from that lecture, where Negus states that he was "brought up in the Listerian tradition" and that those "who worked for Cheyne had the greatest respect and veneration for their chief, and they were imbued with a similar veneration for Lister himself [...]".<ref name="Lister Oration"/>|group="n"}} The postgraduate stages of Negus's training involved specialisation in diseases of the ear, nose and throat, a direction influenced and guided by the otorhinolaryngologist [[St Clair Thomson]] (1857–1943).<ref name="ODNB"/> In the years following his qualification in 1912, Negus worked at King's College Hospital, and had started further clinical training at the Hospital for Diseases of the Throat in [[Golden Square]], Soho, but this was interrupted by the outbreak of the [[First World War]].<ref name="TheTimesObit"/>
Negus served in the [[Royal Army Medical Corps]] (RAMC) with the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|British Expeditionary Force]] for the first 18 months of the war.<ref name="TheTimesObit"/> He initially deployed with the 1st General Hospital, then saw action in the trenches on the front line with a machine-gun battalion at the [[First Battle of Ypres]].<ref name="ODNB"/> The effects of explosives during this period left him with [[tinnitus]].<ref name="TheTimesObit"/> This was followed by a period serving on hospital barges.<ref name="BMJObit"/> In 1916, Negus, still with the RAMC, was posted to the [[3rd (Lahore) Division]] (part of the British Indian Army) and took part in the [[Mesopotamia Campaign]].<ref name="ODNB"/> As one of those who had deployed to the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in the opening months of the war, he was later awarded the [[Mons Star]]. His service in the RAMC ended in 1919.<ref name="WhoWasWho"/>{{#tag:ref|Negus's memoirs from this period were among those deposited in archives at the Royal College of Surgeons of England.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/nra/searches/subjectView.asp?ID=P20988 |title=Negus, Sir Victor (1887–1974) Knight Surgeon |publisher=The National Archives |accessdate=10 March 2012 }}</ref>|group="n"}}
==Surgical career and family== [[File:Larynx external en.svg|thumb|right|The structure of the larynx, in which Negus specialised]] Following his discharge from the army, Negus, again with the advice and guidance of St Clair Thomson, resumed his studies and preparations for a career in throat surgery.<ref name="TheTimesObit"/> By 1921 he had graduated [[MB BS]] (London) [Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery] and by 1922 he had taken the surgical exams for the [[FRCS]] (Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons) qualification.<ref name="ODNB"/> To gain further experience, he spent periods of time abroad studying with renowned laryngologists: firstly with Emil Moure and [[Georges Portmann]] in Bordeaux, France; and secondly with [[Chevalier Jackson]] in Philadelphia, USA.<ref name="BMJObit"/> On his return to London, he became clinical assistant to St Clair Thomson at King's College Hospital.<ref name="TheTimesObit"/>{{#tag:ref|Clinical Assistant was one of the formal grades or ranks that existed in UK hospital medicine at the time. During his career, Negus would progress through these grades, which included Junior Surgeon, Surgeon, and Senior Surgeon. Examples can be seen in the archival records description for patient case notes at King's College Hospital in that period.<ref name="KCLarchives1">{{cite web| url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/depsta/iss/archives/collect/1ki40220.html | title=King's College Hospital Patient Case Notes, 1840–1959| work=King's College London Archives and Corporate Records Services – catalogue| publisher=King's College London Archives| quote=Victor Ewings Negus, Junior Surgeon, Ear, Nose and Throat Department, 1924–1931, Surgeon, 1931–1940, on retirement of Charles Hope, Senior Surgeon, 1940–1946| accessdate=6 April 2012}}</ref>|group="n"}}
At this point, still early in his surgical career, Negus took a different approach to that which was common at the time. Rather than be apprenticed to a leading surgeon in his ENT (ear, nose and throat) speciality, he undertook basic research on the structure of the larynx that would lead to a higher degree in 1924 and the publication of books and papers on the topic in later years.<ref name="AnnalsObit">{{cite journal |last1=Bateman |first1=Geoffrey Hirst |date=October 1974 |title=In memoriam. Sir Victor Ewings Negus. |journal=Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England |volume=55 |issue=4 |pages=201–202 |pmc=2388467 |pmid=4607981}}</ref><ref group="n">For details of Negus's work on comparative anatomy, see the [[#Comparative anatomy|comparative anatomy section]] of this article.</ref> While engaged in this research, Negus continued his work at King's College Hospital, being appointed junior surgeon in 1924.<ref name="ODNB"/> It was during this period, following his return from the USA, that Negus both promoted the methods and tools he had seen used in Philadelphia by Jackson, and worked to improve the designs of the endoscopes and other equipment used in ENT surgery.<ref name="BMJObit"/> These instruments, developed in collaboration with the Genito-Urinary Company of London, included [[laryngoscope]]s, [[bronchoscope]]s (such as the Negus bronchoscope) and [[oesophagoscope]]s.<ref name="BMJObit"/> Other surgical innovations developed by Negus included an [[operating table]] (known as the King's College table), and a speaking valve for use in [[tracheotomy|tracheotomy tubes]].<ref name="TheTimesObit"/> He also helped develop strategies for treatments of throat cancer to aid the choice between surgery and radiotherapy.<ref name="BMJObit"/>
In 1929, Negus married Winifred Adelaide Gladys Rennie (1901–1980, known as Eve){{#tag:ref|This marriage, with the engagement announced in 1928 in ''The Times'',<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Mr V. E. Negus and Miss Rennie | section=Marriages| day_of_week=Monday |date=24 September 1928 |page_number= 17 |issue= 45006|column= B}}</ref> took place around four years after the death of Negus's father, who had died in the period 1924/5; Negus's mother died in 1939. The engagement announcement stated that Gladys (Eve) was daughter to the late Robert Rennie, an engineer.<ref name="ODNB"/>|group="n"}} with whom he would have two sons, David (1930–2010) and Richard (1932–2008).{{#tag:ref|Negus's eldest son David would, like his father, become a consultant surgeon and Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://livesonline.rcseng.ac.uk/biogs/E001840b.htm | title=Negus, David (1930–2010)| work=Plarr's Lives of the Fellows Online| publisher=The Royal College of Surgeons of England| accessdate=24 March 2012}}</ref> David's younger brother Richard did not enter the medical profession, marrying in 1960 and settling in the USA.<ref name="UBCF">{{cite news| url=http://www.united-burmese.org/uploads/4/2/8/9/4289162/ubcf_winter_2011_final.pdf| format=pdf| last=Reeves| first= Nancy L.| title=Korats: A Lifelong Passion – an interview with Daphne Negus |date=Winter 2011| volume=4| issue=1| journal=UBCF Newsletter| publisher=United Burmese Cat Fanciers| pages=6–11}}</ref>|group="n"}} Negus's surgical and medical teaching career continued to progress, and he was appointed surgeon in 1931.<ref name="BMJObit"/> It was in 1937 that his major work in clinical medicine, the fourth edition of ''Diseases of the Nose and Throat'', was published. This work, "still used for reference",<ref name="ODNB"/> was described as "for many years the standard textbook in English on this subject",<ref name="AnnalsObit"/> and as Negus's "major literary contribution to clinical medicine".<ref name="BMJObit"/> The 1937 edition continued work on earlier editions by St Clair Thomson, who worked jointly with Negus on the new edition. A fifth edition worked on by both men was published in 1948 following Thomson's death, and the sixth edition by Negus alone appeared in 1955.<ref name="ODNB"/>
In 1939, the Negus family moved to [[Haslemere]], Surrey.<ref name="ODNB"/> During the [[Second World War]], Negus again served in a medical capacity, this time with the Emergency Medical Service (EMS) at [[Horton Hospital]], Epsom, from 1939 to 1946.<ref name="WhoWasWho"/> In 1940, on the retirement of his colleague Charles Hope,<ref name="KCLarchives1"/> he had been appointed senior surgeon at King's College Hospital, and in 1946 he reached the peak of his profession as a [[consultant (medicine)|consulting surgeon]].<ref name="BMJObit"/> During this post-war period one of Negus's patients was the former (and future) prime minister [[Winston Churchill]], who in 1950 was diagnosed by Negus with high-frequency [[sensorineural hearing loss]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.wdms.org/html/womed_summer04/womed_summer04.htm| title=The Most Important Patient of Our Time| last=Lavelle| first=William G.| date=Summer 2004 | publisher=Worcester District Medical Society| work=Worcester Medicine| accessdate=24 March 2012}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|Churchill and other celebrity patients of Negus were named in an interview given in 2011 by his daughter-in-law Daphne Negus, as part of recollections of her husband Richard: "His family were doctors. Sir Victor Negus, his father, was a Harley Street ENT Specialist whose patients included [[Elizabeth Taylor]], [[Claudette Colbert]], and Sir Winston Churchill."<ref name="UBCF"/>|group="n"}} Negus retired from clinical and teaching work in 1952 at the age of 65.<ref name="TheTimesObit"/>
==Comparative anatomy== {{multiple image | image1 = Kehlkopf Pferd 2.jpg | width1 = 163 | alt1 = | image2 = Larynx of a pig 2.jpg | width2 = 140 | alt2 = | footer = Examples of animal larynges, like those dissected by Negus. At left is the larynx of a horse. At right is the larynx of a pig. }} In parallel with his career as a throat surgeon at a teaching hospital, Negus become a leading expert on the [[comparative anatomy]] of first the [[larynx]] and then the nose and the [[paranasal sinuses]]. This strand of his professional life started with the research he carried out in his thirties in the 1920s that eventually led to his degree of [[Master of Surgery]] (MS), awarded by the [[University of London]].<ref name="TheTimesObit"/> This work started as early as 1921 in the laboratories of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of England]], whose museum housed the collections of animal specimens gathered by the anatomist [[John Hunter (surgeon)|John Hunter]]. Working on these specimens, and adding to them with others supplied by the [[Zoological Society of London]], Negus carried out meticulous dissections that enabled him to trace the stages of evolution and development of the larynx across a wide variety of animals.<ref name="Harrison1995"/> Part of this research was submitted as his thesis, and the excellence of the work was recognised by the award of a Gold Medal with his MS degree in 1924.<ref>{{cite journal |year=1924 |title=Back matter |journal=The Journal of Laryngology & Otology |volume=39 |issue=10 |pages=b1–b5 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=746880&fulltextType=XX&fileId=S0022215100026578 |doi=10.1017/s0022215100026578}}</ref> In addition to this, Negus gave the Arris and Gale Lecture on 28 April 1924 at the Royal College of Surgeons, with his talk titled "On the Mechanism of the Larynx".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Negus |first1=Victor Ewings |date=17 May 1924 |title=On the Mechanism of the Larynx |journal=The Lancet |volume=203 |issue=5255 |pages=987–993 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673601666625 |doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(01)66662-5}}</ref>
Further recognition of his work came when Negus was made Hunterian Professor at the Royal College of Surgeons in 1925,<ref name="WhoWasWho"/> followed three years later in 1928 by the awarding of the triennial John Hunter Medal (1925–7) from the Royal College of Surgeons, which came with a prize of £50.<ref>{{cite journal |date=18 May 1928 |title=Scientific Notes and News |journal=Science |volume=67 |issue=1742 |pages=505–508 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/67/1742/505.full.pdf |format=pdf| quote=The John Hunter Medal in bronze, with the triennial prize of £50, has been awarded by the Royal College of Surgeons of England to Victor Ewings Negus, for his investigations into the comparative anatomy and physiology of the larynx and the bronchi in their relation to surgery. |doi=10.1126/science.67.1742.505|bibcode = 1928Sci....67..505. }}</ref> The following year Negus published his observations and conclusions in ''The Mechanism of the Larynx'' (1929),<ref name="WhoWasWho"/> a "classic piece of research"<ref name="AnnalsObit"/> still referred to forty-five years later in 1974 as "the standard reference book"<ref name="AnnalsObit"/> on this topic. Negus's work had shown that the main function of the larynx is as a valve that only allows air into the lower respiratory tract. In humans, the voice is only a byproduct of this more vital function.<ref name="BMJObit"/> Another lecture resulting from this work was given under the auspices of the University of London's Semon Lectureship, named after the German-born British laryngologist [[Felix Semon]] (1849–1921). This talk was delivered on 6 November 1930 at the [[Royal Society of Medicine]] under the title "Observations on Semon's Law".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Negus |first1=Victor Ewings |year=1931 |title=Observations on Semon's Law |journal=The Journal of Laryngology & Otology |volume=46 |issue=1 |pages=1–30 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=754668 |doi=10.1017/s0022215100035635}}</ref>
These earlier works were followed after the Second World War by the publication of ''Comparative Anatomy and Physiology of the Larynx'' (1949).<ref name="WhoWasWho"/> This work was a condensed and updated version of Negus's original 1929 work on the larynx.<ref>{{cite journal |date=13 May 1950 |title=The Larynx |journal=British Medical Journal | last=Wood Jones| first=Frederic| authorlink=Frederic Wood Jones| volume=1 |issue=4662 |pages=1120–1121 |pmc=2037684 | doi=10.1136/bmj.1.4662.1121}}</ref> It was in this post-war period that Negus would increasingly study the function of the nose, both as the organ for the sense of smell ([[olfaction]]) and the role of the nose in [[respiratory tract|respiration]]. This was prompted by wartime damage in 1941 to the Royal College of Surgeons' Hunterian Museum, which included the loss of parts of the Onodi Collection. This collection had contained specimens of the accessory sinuses (paranasal sinuses) prepared by the Hungarian laryngologist [[Adolf Onodi]] (1857–1919) and demonstrated by him in 1900. Negus undertook to replace the destroyed and damaged specimens and to extend the collection with animal specimens.<ref name="ODNB"/><ref>{{cite journal |date=October 1962 |title=To Acknowledge a Generous and Welcome Gift from Sir Victor Negus |journal=Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England |volume=31 |issue=4 |pages=267–268 |pmc=2413452 |pmid=19310349}}</ref> This work was covered in Negus's Hunterian Lecture, delivered on 20 May 1954 at the Royal College of Surgeons under the title "Introduction to the Comparative Anatomy of the Nose and Paranasal Sinuses".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Negus |first1=Victor Ewings |date=September 1954 |title=Introduction to the Comparative Anatomy of the Nose and Paranasal Sinuses |journal=Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England |volume=15 |issue=3 |pages=141–173 |pmc=2377799 |pmid=13198060}}</ref> This was followed four years later by the publication of ''Comparative Anatomy and Physiology of the Nose and Paranasal Sinuses'' (1958).<ref name="WhoWasWho"/> Much of this later work was carried out after retirement in 1952, both at the laboratories of the Royal College of Surgeons and at the Ferens Institute of Otolaryngology at the [[Middlesex Hospital]].<ref name="AnnalsObit"/> Negus's research over many years on these topics and their relation to nose and throat surgery led to the awarding of the 1954 [[Lister Medal]].<ref>{{cite journal |date=September 1954 |title=Lister Medal |journal=Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England |volume=15 |issue=3 |page=173 |pmc=2377793 |quote=...in recognition of Mr. Negus's services to the advancement of knowledge in the surgery of the nose and throat by means of his researches into the comparative anatomy and physiology of the larynx and paranasal sinuses. |pmid=19309991}}</ref> This was presented the following year when Negus delivered the Lister Oration on 5 April 1955 at the Royal College of Surgeons. The oration was titled "The Comparative Anatomy and Physiology of the Respiratory Tract in Relation to Clinical Problems".<ref name="Lister Oration">{{cite journal |last1=Negus |first1=Victor Ewings |date=May 1955 |title=The Comparative Anatomy and Physiology of the Respiratory Tract in Relation to Clinical Problems |journal=Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England |volume=16 |issue=5 |pages=281–304 |pmc=2377889 |pmid=14377313}}</ref> Ten years later, towards the end of his life, Negus published ''The Biology of Respiration'' (1965).<ref name="WhoWasWho"/>
Negus's legacy in this field was assessed in 1986 by the British surgeon and comparative anatomist Sir [[Donald Frederick Norris Harrison]], himself an expert on the mammalian larynx.<ref name="Harrison1986">{{cite journal |last1=Harrison |first1=Donald Frederick Norris |date=November–December 1986 |title=Victor Negus: 57 years later |journal=Annals of Otology, Rhinology, and Laryngology |volume=95 |issue=6 Pt 1 |pages=561–566 |pmid=3538979|doi=10.1177/000348948609500604 }}</ref> Writing further on the subject in 1995, Harrison states that Negus's "pioneer research into the mechanism of the animal larynx [...] established him as a unique comparative anatomist."<ref name="Harrison1995">See the section 'Sir Victor Negus' (pp.16–17) in {{cite book |title=The Anatomy and Physiology of the Mammalian Larynx |last=Harrison |first=Donald Frederick Norris |year=1995 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |chapter=Introduction |isbn=9780521453219 |pages=1–18}}</ref> Harrison quotes from the Scottish anatomist Sir [[Arthur Keith]]'s preface to ''The Mechanism of the Larynx''. In this preface, Negus's 1929 work is described as showing "the same patient power of assembling observation after observation as Darwin had and some of the hot pursuit of function as urged by Hunter".<ref name="Harrison1995"/>{{#tag:ref|The quote from Keith refers to the 19th-century naturalist [[Charles Darwin]], famed for his theory of evolution, and the 18th-century surgeon and anatomist [[John Hunter (surgeon)|John Hunter]], with whose specimens Negus had been working. This comparison was highlighted in contemporary reviews such as the one that appeared in ''[[Nature (magazine)|Nature]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |date=4 October 1930 |title=Our Bookshelf |journal=Nature |volume=126 |issue=3179 |pages=537 |doi=10.1038/126537a0| url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v126/n3179/abs/126537a0.html|bibcode= 1930Natur.126Q.537.}}</ref>|group="n"}}
==Societies and administration== [[File:Royal College of Surgeons of England 1.jpg|thumb|right|The Royal College of Surgeons of England, at [[Lincoln's Inn Fields]], London]] As one of the leading practitioners in his speciality, Negus served in many roles in its organisation and administration at both a national and international level. In particular, he worked closely with the Royal College of Surgeons of England, the body responsible for the accreditation and representation of surgeons practising in England and Wales, and also the organisation that supported him in his researches in comparative anatomy. The Royal College of Surgeons is located in London, and from 1939 to 1941 he was President of its Listerian Society.<ref name="BMJObit"/>
In 1942, Negus was President of the Section of Laryngology at the Royal Society of Medicine.<ref name="ODNB"/> When Negus had been training as a surgeon, laryngology, rhinology and otology had been part of general surgery, but this was changing with the advent of ENT (ear, nose and throat) medicine as a combined and specialised discipline. Negus and colleagues attempted to set up the necessary structure within the Royal Society of Medicine to represent their profession as an emerging speciality, but the regulations in place would not allow the type of organisation they had planned. This led them, in 1943, to found the British Association of Otorhinolaryngologists which would be able to represent ENT surgeons through the Royal College of Surgeons.<ref name="AnnalsObit"/>{{#tag:ref|More details of the founding of the British Association of Otorhinolaryngologists (BAO) were published in an announcement made in October 1943 in ''The Journal of Laryngology & Otology'' by one of the co-founders Frank Cunliffe Ormerod.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ormerod |first=Frank Cunliffe |date=October 1943| title=British Association of Otolaryngologists |journal=The Journal of Laryngology & Otology |volume=58 |issue=10 |pages=436–437 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=762500 |doi=10.1017/s0022215100011476}}</ref> This organisation subsequently became the British Association of Otorhinolaryngologists – Head and Neck Surgeons (BAO-HNS), which since 2008 has been ENT•UK, which formed as a merger between BAO-HNS and the British Academic Conference in Otolaryngology (BACO).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.entuk.org.uk/about/| title=About ENT•UK| publisher=ENT•UK British Association of Otorhinolaryngologists – Head and Neck Surgeons| accessdate=6 April 2012}}</ref> For more on the early history of the organisation founded by Negus and colleagues, see ''The Role of the British Association of Otolaryngologists (BAOL) in the Development of Otolaryngology in Great Britain from 1943–1968'' (Neil Francis Weir, University of London, 2008).|group="n"}} Following the war, Negus was co-opted to the Council of the Royal College of Surgeons in 1947, and was the first to represent otolaryngology at that level. He was also a member of the college's Court of Examiners, and worked to set up the first examination in otorhinolaryngology that could be taken for the FRCS diploma.<ref name="AnnalsObit"/> This reorganisation was taking place against a background of immense change in how medicine was practised in the UK, due to the advent of the [[National Health Service]] (NHS). Negus's colleague, Geoffrey Bateman, writing in 1974, credits him with having the foresight to represent the interests of otolaryngology and see it established as a major speciality in its own right within the NHS.<ref name="AnnalsObit"/>
Negus became President of the British Association of Otorhinolaryngologists in 1951, and this was one of a number of presidencies he held, including that of the Thoracic Society (1949–50) and the Fourth International Congress of Otolaryngology.<ref name="BMJObit"/> The latter was a large event that took place in London over a week in July 1949. It was held in the Great Hall of King's College, London, and was attended by over 700 otolaryngology specialists from 39 countries. The patron was [[King George VI]] and the congress was opened by the [[Princess Marina of Greece and Denmark|Duchess of Kent]].<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Ear, Nose, And Throat Research Opening of Congress |day_of_week=Tuesday |date=19 July 1949 |page_number= 3 |issue= 51437|column= G}}</ref> Negus was President and host for the 1954 annual meeting of the Collegium Oto-rhino-laryngologicum Amicitiae Sacrum (CORLAS), held in London from 29 August to 1 September,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Huizinga |first=Eelco |year=1954 |title=Ordinary Meeting of the Collegium O.R.L.A.S., London, 29 August–1 September 1954 |journal=Acta Oto-laryngologica |volume=44 |issue=5–6 |pages=389–392 |doi=10.3109/00016485409127646}}</ref> and was the treasurer of CORLAS from 1936 to 1950.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.corlas.org/History.htm| title=History| publisher=Collegium Oto-rhino-laryngologicum Amicitiae Sacrum| accessdate=3 April 2012}}</ref> Negus was also associated with, and gave talks to, numerous medical societies in the UK and abroad, with his connections ranging from honorary fellowships to corresponding and honorary memberships. These foreign societies included the [[American Broncho-Esophagological Association]], and the countries included Sweden, Denmark, Canada, the USA, Austria, France, Italy, Hungary, and Turkey.<ref name="WhoWasWho"/>{{#tag:ref|The entry for Negus in ''Who Was Who'' includes a listing of these societies.<ref name="WhoWasWho"/>|group="n"}} Bateman opined in his obituary of Negus that it seemed unlikely that any other British ENT surgeon "has been honoured by so many societies".<ref name="AnnalsObit"/>
Following his retirement, Negus continued his involvement with the Royal College of Surgeons, becoming a trustee (and later chairman of the trustees) of the Hunterian Collection, the same collection that included the specimens that had underpinned his research some thirty years earlier.<ref name="BMJObit"/> He also published books on the history of the college and its collections: ''The History of the Trustees of the Hunterian Collection'' (1965); and ''The Artistic Possessions at the Royal College of Surgeons of England'' (1968).<ref name="ODNB"/><ref name="AnnalsObit"/>
==Honours, awards and legacy== In his later years, Negus received many awards and honours. In 1945, he was made a Fellow of King's College, London.<ref name="ODNB"/>{{#tag:ref|The Fellowship and Honorary Fellowship of King's College, London (designated FKC) is not a research appointment, but is rather an award, established in 1847, and conferred "in recognition of [...] exceptional achievement and/or service rendered to the College".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/aboutkings/governance/committees/fellowshipsFAQs2010.pdf | title=Fellowships and Honorary Degrees: Frequently Asked Questions | publisher=King's College, London | format=pdf| accessdate=6 April 2012}}</ref>|group="n"}} On 25 July 1949, he received the honorary fellowship of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]].<ref>{{cite journal |date=6 August 1949 |title=Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=2 |issue=4622 |page=341 |quote=At a reception held on July 25 the Honorary Fellowship of the College was conferred on Mr. Victor Ewings Negus. M.S., F.R.C.S., President of the Fourth International Congress of Otolaryngology held in London last month... |pmc=2050569|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2050569/pdf/brmedj03636-0028b.pdf}}</ref> Further tributes followed as an honorary [[Doctor of Science]] (D.Sc.) was conferred on him on 17 May 1950 by the [[University of Manchester]].<ref>{{cite journal |date=1 April 1950 |title=University of Manchester |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=1 |issue=4656 |pages=794–795 |pmc=2037099| quote=On Founder's Day, May 17, the honorary degree of D.Sc. will be conferred on Victor Ewings Negus, M.S., F.R.C.S., Surgeon to the Ear, Nose, and Throat Department, King's College Hospital, for his contributions to medical research, particularly in laryngology... |pmid=20787844}}</ref> Back in London, the Royal Society of Medicine made him an honorary fellow in 1954.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Royal Society of Medicine |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=21 July 1954 |page_number= 8 |issue= 52989|column= B}}</ref> Two years later, Negus was made a [[knight bachelor]] with the investiture taking place at [[Buckingham Palace]] on 7 February 1956.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=40706 |date=10 February 1956 |page=825}}</ref> On 28 August 1958, it was the turn of the [[Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland]] to bestow their honorary fellowship on him.<ref>{{cite journal |date=November 1958 |title=Honorary Fellowships at the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland |journal=Irish Journal of Medical Science (1926–1967) |volume=33 |issue=1 |pages=523–524 |doi=10.1007/BF02951596| url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/7m0382228881535t/}}</ref> In addition to these awards, Negus continued to give lectures, including an Erasmus Wilson demonstration awarded by the Royal College of Surgeons of England in 1953,<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Royal College of Surgeons |day_of_week=Friday |date=9 January 1953 |page_number= 8 |issue= 52515|column= E}}</ref> and the Johns Hopkins Lecture on 30 April 1957.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Negus |first1=Victor Ewings |date=October 1957 |title=The Etiology of Pharyngeal Diverticula |journal=Bulletin of the Johns Hopkins Hospital |volume=101 |issue=4 |pages=209–223 |pmid=13472247}}</ref> Negus also received the 1963 Gould Award from the William and Harriet Gould Foundation of Chicago, USA, "for his monumental contributions to the science of laryngology".<ref>{{cite journal |year=1964 |title=Back matter |journal=The Journal of Laryngology & Otology |volume=78 |issue=6 |pages=b1–b5 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract;jsessionid=DDD47ED4BC37A318122FF05A0B5A8FFD.journals?fromPage=online&aid=1154988 |doi=10.1017/s0022215100062666}}</ref>
On 13 February 1969, Negus and two others (Sir [[Geoffrey Keynes]] and Sir [[Stanford Cade]]) were presented with the Honorary Gold Medal of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. This award, which had only been made thirty times since 1802 prior to the 1969 ceremony, is presented for "liberal acts or distinguished labours, researches and discoveries, eminently conducive to the improvement of natural knowledge and of the healing art."<ref name="HonGoldMedal">{{cite journal|date=March 1969 |title=Award of the Honorary Medal of the College |journal=Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England |volume=44 |issue=3 |pages=169–171 |pmc=2387590}}</ref> The medal was presented by Sir [[Hedley Atkins]], the President of the Royal College of Surgeons, who paid tribute to Negus: "Sir Victor Negus is perhaps the most distinguished of all those who have served the Council as a co-opted member. He has always been known to us as a great research worker and scientist, whose labours earned him the Lister Medal, a man of exceptional integrity and industry and a persistent advocate of the value of tradition in its best sense."<ref name="HonGoldMedal"/> Atkins also paid tribute to Negus's wife, Lady Negus, who had crafted and presented to the college a tapestry of its coat-of-arms. Responding, Negus thanked the members of the Council for the award and for the privilege of having used college facilities since 1921, concluding: "I take this honour as a mark of approval for any work I have done, and I feel I can now sit back and leave it to others to carry on. I would also like to thank you for inviting my wife to be here to-day; she has taken a great part in all I have done."<ref name="HonGoldMedal"/>{{#tag:ref|Both the [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] entry for Negus, by consultant ENT surgeon Neil Weir, and Bateman's obituary in the [[Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England]], give details of the role played by Negus's wife Eve, describing her as "an artist of considerable merit" who illustrated several of his books.<ref name="ODNB"/><ref name="AnnalsObit"/>|group="n"}}
Negus died in [[Hindhead]], Surrey, on 15 July 1974, at the age of 87, survived by his wife and children.<ref name="ODNB"/>{{#tag:ref|Negus's widow, Lady Negus, died six years later on 15 October 1980.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Lady Negus | day_of_week=Tuesday |date=21 October 1980 |page_number= 15 |issue= 60755|column= G}}</ref>|group="n"}} Negus's status in the history of laryngology in the UK was remarked on in his obituary in ''The Times'', which stated that he "made a worthy fourth to [[Morell Mackenzie]], Felix Semon, and St Clair Thomson".<ref name="TheTimesObit"/> Obituaries also appeared in a range of medical journals.{{#tag:ref|Examples of such obituaries include those that appeared in ''The Lancet'', the ''Journal of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh'', and ''Revue de Laryngologie, Otologie, Rhinologie'', the latter by Georges Portmann with whom Negus had studied some five decades earlier.<ref>{{cite journal| date=27 July 1974 |title=Victor Ewings Negus |journal=The Lancet |volume=2 |issue=7874 |pages=234–235 |pmid=4135666|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(74)91549-9 }}; {{cite journal | last1=Fish| first1=W.| last2=Campbell| first2=J. M.|date=November 1974 |title=In memoriam. Sir Victor Ewings Negus. |journal=Journal of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh |volume=19 |issue=6 |page=394 | pmid=4613828}}; {{cite journal | last=Portmann| first=Georges|date=January–February 1975 |title=Sir Victor Negus 1887–1974 |journal=Revue de Laryngologie, Otologie, Rhinologie (Bordeaux) |volume=96 |issue=1–2 |pages=99–100 | pmid=1096259}}</ref>|group="n"}} In due course, biographical entries appeared in volume 6 of ''Lives of the Fellows of the Royal College of Surgeons of England'' (1988) and in the [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] (2004).<ref name="ODNB"/><ref>{{cite encyclopedia| title=Sir Victor Ewings Negus| editor1-last=Cornelius| editor1-first=Eustace Hope| editor2-last=Taylor| editor2-first=Selwyn| encyclopedia=Lives of the Fellows of the Royal College of Surgeons of England, 1974–1982| year=1988| publisher=Royal College of Surgeons of England| isbn=978-0902166035| page=290}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|Negus was one of a range of medical and surgical figures whose portraits and brief biographies featured in a history of the Royal College of Surgeons of England, published in 2000 to mark its 200th anniversary. The entry for Negus is in the otolarnygology section of Chapter 15, 'Surgical Specialisation: Emergence of the Specialist Associations'.<ref>'Sir Victor Ewings Negus' in {{cite book| last1=Blandy| first1=John Peter| last2=Lumley| first2=John| last3=Lumley| first3=John Stuart Penton| title=The Royal College of Surgeons of England: 200 Years of History at the Millennium| year=2000| publisher=Wiley-Blackwell| isbn=978-0632053964| at=fig. 15.16, p.139}}</ref>|group="n"}} Two photographic portraits of Negus are held in the collections of the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]] in London.{{#tag:ref|The first photograph, by the Lafayette studio (see [[James Lafayette]]), is from 1928.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw174016/Sir-Victor-Ewings-Negus | title=Sir Victor Ewings Negus | publisher=National Portrait Gallery (London) | work=Collections| accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref> The second photograph, by the [[Elliott & Fry|Elliott & Fry studio]], is from 1956.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw102332/Sir-Victor-Ewings-Negus | title=Sir Victor Ewings Negus | publisher=National Portrait Gallery (London) | work=Collections| accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref>|group="n"}} As well as archives relating to Negus, the Royal College of Surgeons of England houses in its one of its reserve collections (the Hunterian Museum Collection) over 200 sagittal sections of animals dissected by him.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.rcseng.ac.uk/museums/history/collections.html | title=Reserve collections | publisher=The Royal College of Surgeons of England | work=Museums and Archives; History; Collections| accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref> Additional collections of bisected animal heads prepared by Negus are held at the [[Grant Museum of Zoology and Comparative Anatomy]] in London.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/museums/zoology/collections | title=Collection Highlights | publisher=University College London | work=UCL Museums & Collections; Grant Museum of Zoology; The Collections | accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref>
